([[Hong Kong]], [[People's Republic of China|China]]; 17 November 2010) | World cup apps = | World cup first = | World cup best = | Regional name = [[AFC Asian Cup|Asian Cup]] | Regional cup apps = 3 | Regional cup first = [[1956 AFC Asian Cup|1956]] | Regional cup best = Third Place, [[1956 AFC Asian Cup|1956]] | 2ndRegional name = [[East Asian Football Championship|EAFF Championship]] | 2ndRegional cup apps = 4 | 2ndRegional cup first = [[1995 East Asian Dynasty Cup|1995]] | 2ndRegional cup best = Third Place, [[1995 East Asian Dynasty Cup|1995]] }} The '''Hong Kong national football team''' ({{zh|c=é¦æ¸¯è¶³çä»£è¡¨é}}), represents [[Hong Kong]] in international [[association football]] events such as the [[FIFA World Cup]], [[AFC Asian Cup]] and [[East Asian Football Championship]]. The team is represented by the [[Hong Kong Football Association]]. The team had been representing Hong Kong in international football events before 1997 when Hong Kong was a [[British overseas territory|colony]] of the United Kingdom. It continues to represent Hong Kong even after Hong Kong was [[Transfer of the sovereignty of Hong Kong|handed over]] to the People's Republic of China by the United Kingdom and became a [[special administrative region (People's Republic of China)|special administrative region]] of the People's Republic of China in 1997. This team is a separate team from the [[China national football team|national team]] of the [[People's Republic of China]], as the [[Hong Kong Basic Law|Basic Law]] and the principle of "[[One country, two systems]]" allows Hong Kong to maintain its own representative teams in international sports competitions. ==History== Hong Kong played its first international match after [[World War II]] in 1949, against [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]]. Its first victory came in 1953, a 4-0 win against [[South Korea national football team|South Korea]]. Hong Kong qualified for three of the first four editions of the [[Asian Cup]], including a third place finish in [[Asian Cup 1956|1956]] as hosts. Hong Kong has never qualified for the [[Football World Cup|World Cup]]. However, its most celebrated victory happened during [[Football World Cup 1986 (qualification)|1986 World Cup qualifying]]. On 19 May 1985, in Beijing, Hong Kong faced [[China national football team|China]] in the final match of the first qualifying round, where Hong Kong needed a win to advance while China needed only a draw. Hong Kong, led by coach [[Kwok Ka Ming]], produced a [[China v Hong Kong (1985)|2-1 upset win]], with goals from [[Cheung Chi Tak]] and [[Ku Kam Fai]], thereby winning the group and advancing to the knockout stage, where it subsequently lost to [[Japan national football team|Japan]]. On 9 February 2005, to celebrate the 90th anniversary of both the Association and the [[Brazilian Football Confederation]], Hong Kong hosted [[Football World Cup 2002|2002 World Cup]] champions [[Brazil national football team|Brazil]] in a friendly match, with [[Lee Sze Ming]] scoring the only goal for Hong Kong, although Brazil won 7-1. The year 2009 could be a turning point in the diminishing football standards of Hong Kong. On the 12th of December, Hong Kong defeated Japan and took their first [[Football at the 2009 East Asian Games|East Asian Games football]] gold medal in the first major competition Hong Kong football team have won. This unexpected and surprising result, raised the belief that the Hong Kong football team could perform for football lovers in Hong Kong. The Hong Kong football team also won the [[2010 Long Teng Cup]] and [[2011 Long Teng Cup]] ==Stadium== Hong Kong plays its home matches at the [[Hong Kong Stadium]], where they are also hosting an annual international tournament known as the [[Carlsberg Cup]] as part of the festivities to usher in the Chinese New Year. Hong Kong also uses the [[Siu Sai Wan Sports Ground]] in [[Chai Wan]] and the [[Mong Kok Stadium]] in [[Mong Kok]]. ==Competition history== :''See comprehensive article: [[Hong Kong national football team - record in qualifying and major tournaments]]'' :''Denotes draws includes knockout matches decided on [[penalty shootout (football)|penalty kicks]].'' ===Asian Games record===
